text: Acetylsalicylic acid and sodium salicylate inhibit LPS - induced NF-kappa B / <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> nuclear translocation , and synthesis of <extra_id_0> tissue factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alfa <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) in human monocytes .

We have investigated the effects of acetylsalicylic acid and sodium salicylate on the LPS - induced synthesis of the pro-coagulant protein tissue factor ( TF ) and the pro-inflammatory protein <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , as well as the prostaglandin PGE2 in human monocytes .
Both drugs dose-dependently inhibited LPS - induced TF and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis at the mRNA and the protein level , and reduced PGE2 production .

As evidenced by electro mobility shift assay ( EMSA ) and the use of a NF-kappa B prototypic probe , these drugs probably exert their inhibitory effects by interference with the nuclear translocation of NF-kappa B / <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins .
These data may expand the understanding of the anti-thrombotic and anti-inflammatory effects of these drugs when activation of monocytes occurs .
